Graphical abstract NbN quantum dots anchored to nitrogen-doped hollow carbon nanorods are designed to solve LiPSs shuttling effect and lithium dendrite growth, thereby showing superior electrochemical performance for Li-S battery. The shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and uncontrollable lithium dendrite growth seriously hinder the practical application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. To simultaneously address such issues, monodispersed NbN quantum dots anchored on nitrogen-doped hollow carbon nanorods (NbN@NHCR) are elaborately developed as efficient LiPSs immobilizer and Li stabilizer for high-performance Li-S full batteries. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental characterizations demonstrate that the sulfiphilic and lithiophilic NbN@NHCR hybrid can not only efficiently immobilize the soluble LiPSs and facilitate diffusion-conversion kinetics for alleviating the shuttling effect, but also homogenize the distribution of Li+ ions and regulate uniform Li deposition for suppressing Li-dendrite growth. As a result, the assembled Li-S full batteries (NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li) deliver excellent long-term cycling stability with a low decay rate of 0.031% per cycle over 1000 cycles at high rate of 2 C. Even at a high S loading of 5.8 mg cm−2 and a low electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 5.2 µL mg−1, a large areal capacity of 6.2 mA h cm−2 can be achieved in Li-S pouch cell at 0.1 C. This study provides a new perspective via designing a dual-functional sulfiphilic and lithiophilic hybrid to address serious issues of the shuttle effect of S cathode and dendrite growth of Li anode. Keywords Dual-functional host NbN quantum dots Shuttle effect Dendrite-free Li anode Li-S full batteries 1 Introduction The rapid growing energy demand is driving the development of lithium-metal-based energy storage systems. With respect to alternative competitors, lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries have been identified as an ideal substitute owing to their dominant energy density (2600 W h kg−1), high theoretical capacity (Li: 3860 mA h g−1 and S: 1675 mA h g−1), and low redox reduction potential of Li metal (−3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) [1–4]. Despite these fascinating merits, the commercial viability of conventional Li-S batteries pointing at durability and safety is still plagued with various arduous challenges and intractable obstacles concerned with S cathode and Li anode. With regard to the cathode, the so-called “shuttling effect” of soluble intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) in the electrolyte will trigger insufficient consumption of active sulfur species and sluggish diffusion-conversion kinetics [5–7]. As for the anode, infinite volume change, uncontrollable dendrite growth, and instable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) will lead to inferior Coulombic efficiency (CE), electrical short circuits, and even a potential safety hazard [8–10]. Consequently, it is desirable for the ingenious design of an advanced Li-S battery system to synchronously blueprint a LiPSs-suppressed cathode and a dendrite-free anode framework [11–13]. Aiming at the major bottlenecks listed above in Li-S batteries, tremendous efforts have been dedicated to circumventing the LiPSs shuttle and Li dendrite growth in recent years [14–19]. For the S cathode side, diverse highly conductive and large surface area carbon skeletons, including graphene [20,21], carbon nanotubes [22,23], and porous carbon [24,25], are initially applied as the host matrix and LiPSs regulator to improve the conductivity of S cathode, attenuate the volume expansion of electrode, and suppress the shuttle effect via physically immobilizing LiPSs. Unfortunately, non-polar carbon materials present weak physical confinement on polar LiPSs, which are tough to satisfy high electrochemical stability under high sulfur loadings and long cycling. Surprisingly, varied transition-metal oxides [26,27], sulfides [28,29], and phosphides [30,31] with strong chemical anchoring for LiPSs and high conductivity have been reasonably brought forward as catalytic additives into Li-S batteries for effectively confining the shuttle effect of LiPSs and facilitating sulfur redox kinetics. Pertaining to Li anode, conquering the Li-dendrite barriers have mainly centered upon using electrolyte additives [32], building up a stable artificial SEI [33], and designing lithiophilic Li hosts [34,35] to homogenize the distribution of Li+ ions and regulate uniform Li deposition behavior. At this point, the Li hosts with the lithiophilic feature are promising for inhibiting Li-dendrite growth and enduring the enormous volume expansion of Li anode during repeated plating and stripping processes. For instance, He et al. demonstrated that a three-dimensional (3D) framework constructed by lithiophilic CoSe nanoparticles embedded in conductive carbon nanowires enabled adequate void space to endure volume fluctuation and guide planar Li deposition [36]. Chen et al. studied the 3D conductive N-doped carbon fibers integrated with uniformly distributed bimetallic Ni-Co particles, which were regarded as lithiophilic sites to efficaciously reduce the Li nucleation overpotential and adjust the spatial electric field [37]. Aside from the reported transition metal catalysts, Nb-based materials have recently raised immense attention in Li-S batteries, resulting from their excellent electrocatalytic and high electronic conductivity [38,39]. For instance, heterostructured C2N@NbSe2 serving as multifunctional polysulfide mediators can accelerate the “adsorption-diffusion-conversion” of LiPSs, exhibiting high initial capacity and impressive cycling stability [40]. Besides, a carbon nanofiber frame with ultrafine Nb2O5-NbC heterostructure achieves ultralow capacity degradation of 0.044% per cycle over 800 cycles at 1 C, owing to the effective LiPSs regulation and improved redox kinetics [41]. As one of the transition metal nitrides, the unique combination of high electronic conductivity and chemical stability makes polar NbN a promising candidate for sulfur host materials and coating separator materials in Li-S batteries. In spite of the encouraging progress on employing Nb-based materials as sulfur hosts, there are rarely few literature reports related to exploring the niobium nitride (NbN) as a lithiophilic host matrix in Li-metal batteries. To address the difficulties faced by both Li anode and S cathode, the “two-in-one” strategy for designing a dual-function host as a bifunctional LiPSs immobilizer and Li stabilizer is expected to simultaneously speed up sulfur redox kinetics and control Li deposition, which is of great significance but still remains challenging. Inspired by the aforementioned considerations, herein, we propose the derived ordered interconnected N-doped porous hollow carbon nanorods embedded by monodispersed NbN quantum dots (NbN@NHCR), which was applied as an advanced dual-functional host skeleton for both S cathode (NbN@NHCR-S) and Li anode (NbN@NHCR-Li) simultaneously. Supported by comprehensive experimental analysis results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the NbN@NHCR presents remarkable lithiophilicity and sulfiphilicity features in Li-S full batteries, which is ascribed to a kinetics-enhanced S cathode and a dendrite-inhibited Li anode. Such a versatile S cathode host for NbN@NHCR with integrated porous, conductive, and polar peculiarities further facilitates physical and chemical confinement and highly efficient electrocatalytic conversions of LiPSs for alleviating the shuttling effect. When employed as a Li anode host, the rationally ordered spatial arrangement of conductive skeletons embedded with rich lithophilic sites enables undeviating current distribution and Li+ ions flux, and regulates uniform Li nucleation/growth for suppressing Li-dendrite growth. As a result, the assembled Li-S full batteries (NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li) deliver long-cycle stability (a low decay rate of 0.031% per cycle over 1000 cycles at 2 C) and outstanding rate performance. Even at a high S loading of 5.8 mg cm−2 and a lean electrolyte/sulfur ratio (E/S) of 5.2 µL mg−1, the soft-package Li-S battery exhibits a promising areal capacity of 6.2 mA h cm−2 at 0.1 C. 2 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the schematic of NbN@NHCR synthesis strategy, which starts from a mixture of ammonium niobate oxalate hydrate, urea, and melamine via a simple in-situ one-step annealing process. The NbN@NHCR displays the hollow nanorod morphology from the representative scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Fig. 1b and Fig. S1). The fascinating hollow architecture can not only effectively facilitate rapid electrolyte infiltration and provide abundant reaction sites for efficient sulfur loading and utilization, but also serve as confinement space for releasing mechanical strain and guaranteeing nanostructure stability during sulfur conversion reactions [28,42,43]. As shown in Fig. 1(c and d), the low-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images corroborate the nanorods feature of NbN@NHCR in accordance with the analysis in the SEM results. High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image reveals that large amounts of quantum dots with an average diameter of 1–2 nm are homogeneously disseminated on the surface of the whole NHCR (Fig. 1e). The fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) characterization are applied to exactly identify the composition of quantum dots. Based on the FFT pattern (Fig. 1f) in the yellow box region of Fig. 1(e), the spacing of adjacent lattice fringes confirmed by the IFFT image (Fig. 1g) is 0.22 nm, acknowledging the (200) crystal plane of NbN [44]. Similarly, the interplanar distance is 0.16 and 0.25 nm, which can be assigned to the (220) and (111) plane of NbN (Fig. S2), respectively. Fig. 1(h) provides the high-angle annular darkfield (HAADF) image and corresponding energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping for NbN@NHCR, which indicates the homogeneous distribution Nb, N, and C elements, confirming the existence of uniformly dispersed NbN quantum dots in N-doped hollow carbon nanorods. For comparison, the NHCR clearly illustrates the hollow morphology without the NbN quantum dots observed after alkali washing (Fig. S3a–c), revealing a well-preserved structural integrity without any collapse. The HAADF image and EDS mapping (Fig. S3d) also demonstrate the even spatial distribution of C and N elements in the synthesized NHCR. For the X-ray diffraction (XRD) result (Fig. S4), the as-prepared NHCR sample only exhibits the diffraction peaks of carbon consistent with the EDS mapping. It should be noted that pure NbN was obtained in the absence of urea during the synthesis process. Besides, the morphology of sample is no longer that of quantum dots (Fig. S5a–d), but that of nanoplates compounded from aggregated NbN nanoparticles, testifying that urea with the aid of metal catalysts plays an essential role in endorsing the formation of hollow carbon nanorods during high-temperature pyrolysis [45]. Additionally, the densely packed NbN harms the full exposure and utilization of active sites. The FFT and corresponding IFFT patterns (Fig. S5e and f) further confirm the (111) plane of NbN with a fringe spacing of 0.25 nm. Moreover, the TEM-HAADF image and corresponding EDS mapping (Fig. S5g) demonstrate the coexistence of Nb and N elements in NbN. The XRD patterns of NbN and NbN@NHCR (Fig. 2 a) both show the typical characteristic diffraction peaks, which are well indexed to NbN (JCPDS No.38-1155) [44]. Meanwhile, XRD peak changes of synthesized products and time-dependent morphological difference are further proved (Figs. S6 and S7). With the annealing time being prolonged, the peak intensity of NbN@NHCR is gradually increased. It is worth noting that NbN@NHCR-1 (pyrolysis for 1 h) and NbN@NHCR-2 (pyrolysis for 2 h) both keep the original 3D morphology, whereas the partial structural collapse can be observed in NbN@NHCR-4 (pyrolysis for 4 h). Taken together, 2 h is the optimal reaction time. Raman spectroscopy was acquired to detect the graphitization degree of as-obtained samples. The two Raman characteristic peaks at 1345 cm−1 (D band) and 1589 cm−1 (G band) correspond to disorder and graphtic carbon, respectively (Fig. 2b) [46]. The intensity ratio of the D and G bands (I D/I G) for the NbN@NHCR is lower than that for NHCR, illustrating the higher graphitization degree of carbon in NbN@NHCR due to the dual catalysis with NbN quantum dots and NHCR. Significantly, the characteristic peak of NbN is not observed in the Raman spectra, which is ascribed to the ultrasmall size of the quantum dots. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (Fig. 2c) manifests that NbN@NHCR possesses a type-IV curve with H1 hysteresis loops [9,17]. The corresponding pore size distribution (inset of Fig. 2c) confirms the typical mesoporous and microporous feature, and pore size is mostly accumulated at 5–10 nm. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area is estimated to be 323.3 m2 g−1 for NbN@NHCR, which is much higher than that of NHCR (238.5 m2 g−1) and NbN (44.3 m2 g−1) (Fig. S8a and b). Such a large BET surface area and porous structure for NbN@NHCR can be attributed to the 3D conductive skeletons integrated with quantum dots, thus contributing to the exposure of active sites and the enhancement of physical confinement for LiPSs [37,47]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further examined to determine the surface chemical compositions. The Nb 3d spectrum of NbN@NHCR can all be separated into three pairs of peaks located at 210.3/207.5, 209.0/205.8, and 207.8/204.2 eV, which can be attributed to Nb–O, Nb–N–O, and Nb–N bonds, respectively (Fig. 2d) [48]. The high-resolution N 1s spectrum (Fig. 2e) can be divided into four peaks representative for Nb–N bonding, pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N bonding located at 396.0, 399.1, 400.3, and 402.1 eV, respectively, on account of the coexistence of the N element in partially surface-oxidized NbN and N-doped carbon frameworks [49]. The N-heteroatom doping is beneficial for improving the adsorption of host materials for Li atoms and LiPSs. The C 1s spectrum (Fig. 2f) displays four characteristic peaks at 284.1, 285.2, 286.3, and 289.0 eV, belonging to the C–C, C=C, C–N, and C–O bonds, respectively [44,50]. As shown in Fig. S9, the weight content of NbN in NbN@NHCR can be calculated as 54.14% based on the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Given that Li-dendrite growth is facile to raise battery short circuits and trigger fire accidents, this further restricts the real-world implementation of Li-S batteries. There is an urgent need for designing a robust and safe Li anode to motivate high-performance Li-S full batteries. To fully dig into the potential of NbN@NHCR as a host matrix in the dendrite-free Li anode, NbN@NHCR sample was coated on the copper foil as the Li dendrite inhibitor. In general, the process of Li deposition is mainly composed of Li nucleation and growth. Thus, the host materials need to have superior lithophilic properties and high Li+ ions migration ability. To better comprehend the lithiophilic mechanism of host materials, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to investigate the binding energies of Li atoms absorbed on different species. The optimized adsorption models are exhibited in Fig. 3 (a and b) and Figs. S10–S12. NbN possesses a larger Li adsorption energy than graphitic C, graphitic N, pyridinic N, and pyrrolic N at each adsorption site, which manifests a stronger interaction between Li and NbN, in favor of the decrease of nucleation overpotential and redistribution of Li flux [33,51]. From the density of states curves in Fig. S13, it is obvious that NbN shows no gap of states at the Fermi level, manifesting its robust metallic character with high conductivity, which not only can homogenize electric field distribution and decrease local current density at the interface of Li anode, but also facilitate rapid electron transfer dynamics between LiPSs and electrocatalysts. Furthermore, the prominent dendrite inhibition behavior for NbN@NHCR is intuitively verified by virtue of the galvanostatic Li plating technique. Fig. 3(c–f) depicts the surface appearances of the bare Cu foil, NHCR-Li, NbN-Li, and NbN@NHCR-Li with a fixed Li deposition capacity of 6 mA h cm−2 or 12 mA h cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2. Obviously, extensively uneven Li dendrites can be distinctly observed after plating at 6 mA h cm−2 for bare Cu foil, owing to the weak affinity to Li+ ions. In a vast contrast, the surface of NbN@NHCR is blanketed with a uniform Li-deposited layer without any Li dendrites forming, benefiting from a 3D porous carbon framework integrated with lithiophilic NbN [52]. Under an even higher plating capacity of 12 mA h cm−2, no dendrites are also observed, demonstrating that the lithiophilic NbN quantum dots can effectively homogenize Li+ ions flow and decrease local current density. The corresponding cross-sectional SEM images of NbN@NHCR upon 6 and 12 mA h cm−2 of Li deposition are shown in Fig. S14. The behavior of NbN@NHCR to regulate Li deposition was researched through the cell configuration paired with various hosts as the working electrode and Li foil as the counter electrode. After precycling between 0 and 1 V for 5 cycles to stabilize the SEI film and clean surface impurities (Fig. S15) [36,53], the NbN@NHCR electrode displays the lowest nucleation overpotentials of 24.5 mV at 1 mA cm−2 with plating capacity of 1 mA h cm−2, which is obviously lower than Cu-Li (60.3 mV), NHCR-Li (47.7 mV), and NbN-Li (33.2 mV), suggesting the great lithiophilicity of NbN@NHCR for facilitating Li nucleation and reducing Li deposition resistance (Fig. 3g) [54]. In the subsequent Li plating and stripping process, the CE was collected to estimate the reversibility of Li on all the host materials. Nevertheless, pure Cu electrode shows a relatively low CE after dozens of cycles and suffers dramatic fluctuations induced by the uncontrollable Li deposition. In stark contrast, the CE remains steady at a higher level (∼99% over 200 cycles) for NbN@NHCR electrode at 1 mA cm−2 with 1 mA h cm−2 (Fig. 3h), certifying high cycling stability and excellent lithiophilicity. Similarly, the corresponding XRD pattern and SEM image of the Li-Cu cell with NbN@NHCR host after cycles confirm the phase and structure stability during cycling (Fig. S16). Considering the plating/stripping stability for Li metal anodes as an important part of overall battery performance, the long-term stability with different hosts was further evaluated at various current densities and capacities using Li symmetrical cells. After a deposition capacity of 3, 6, or 12 mA h cm−2, the surface of NbN@NHCR host is gradually shielded by a dense and smooth metallic Li layer (Fig. 3i–l). With the pre-deposition capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2, the glorious cycling stability of more than 1000 h with a stable overpotential of approximately 9.3 mV is comprehended for symmetric NbN@NHCR-Li batteries (Fig. 3m). As for Li||Li symmetrical cell, a limited cycle lifespan with markedly fluctuating voltage hysteresis is observed, resulting from the formation of undesirable Li dendrites and an unstable SEI layer on the Li anode surface. The NbN@NHCR-Li||NbN@NHCR-Li cell also inherits the smallest overpotential with a long cycle stability of over 1000 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 and a plating/striping time of 4 h (Fig. S17). Admittedly, the large current density is extremely unfavorable for the homogenization of Li+ ions flow, further increasing the polarization and inducing Li dendrite growth [55]. Interestingly, even at a higher current density of 5 mA cm−2, the voltage curve for NbN@NHCR electrode still harvests a comparatively smooth voltage amplitude with a highly stable overpotential (39.6 mV). For comparison, the voltage hysteresis for Li||Li and NHCR-Li||NHCR-Li cells behaves in drastic voltage oscillation after 100 and 200 h, respectively, illustrating their ineffective dendrite-suppressing capability (Fig. 3n). This is yet further proof that the high lithiophilicity of NbN@NHCR is more conducive to rapid electron/ion transfer and efficient Li plating/stripping. Impressively, the rate performance also confirms that the NbN@NHCR-Li anode enables the lowest voltage hysteresis and the most stable polarization vibration at a capacity of 0.5 mA h cm−2 when the current densities are switched from 0.5 to 5 mA cm−2 and switched back to 0.5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3o). The superior dendrite-inhibiting capability of NbN@NHCR can be evidenced by the post-cycle SEM observations (Fig. S18). Unlike undesirable aggregations and cracks on the surface of a bare Cu-Li electrode, the surface for NbN@NHCR-Li anode still maintains a smooth and flat Li deposition layer without uneven deposition and dendrite growth after the rate tests. It can be concluded that the brilliant cycling stability and reversibility in NbN@NHCR-Li||NbN@NHCR-Li cells should be credited with the highly conductive 3D mesoporous construction and embedded lithiophilic NbN, which is advantageous in reducing the local current density during the repeat Li plating/stripping processes, thereby sequentially realizing the improved Li transportation kinetics. To shed more light on assessing the comprehensive improvement of electrochemical performances for the dual-functional NbN@NHCR electrode, the NbN@NHCR-Li anode and the NbN@NHCR-S cathode were coupled as a Li-S full battery (Fig. 4 a). The sulfur content in the NbN@NHCR-S was tested and found to be 79.8 wt% by TGA (Fig. S19). The NbN@NHCR-S with an average diameter of ∼150 nm can well maintain the stable structure and no agglomerated sulfur particles are observed in the SEM and TEM images (Fig. S20a–d). The HAADF images also demonstrate that Nb, N, C, and S elements are uniformly distributed over the entire NbN@NHCR-S (Fig. S20e). The XRD pattern, Raman spectrum, and Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of NbN@NHCR-S presented in Figs. S21–S23 provide the electrochemical characterization of the NbN@NHCR-S cathode, which shows great competitiveness with reported NbN-based cathode and other reported metal nitrides in high performance Li-S batteries (Tables S1 and S2). The CV curves obtained from three Li-S full cells were performed within a 1.7–2.8 V voltage range (Fig. 4b and Fig. S24a–c), exhibiting the well-defined cathodic and anodic peaks in the invertible conversion of active sulfur to LiPSs [10,26,56–58]. The Li+ ion diffusion rate reflects the ability of the catalyst to accelerate the sulfur conversion reaction. The CV tests under various sweep rates in the range of 0.1–0.5 mV s−1 are displayed in Fig. S24(d–f). It is noted that the NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li cell displays a smaller polarization and a higher current at all scanning rates, indicating enhanced redox reaction kinetics. The Li+ ion diffusion coefficients (D Li+) for three peaks were obtained from the fitting of linear curves between the peak current and scan rates according to the Randles-Sevcik equation (Fig. S24g–i) [7,59]. Notably, the NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li cell delivers higher D Li+ values than NHCR and NbN full cells (Fig. S25 and Table S3), manifesting that NbN@NHCR electrode realizes enhanced chemisorption ability of LiPSs and promotes redox reaction kinetics to avert LiPSs from dissolving into the electrolyte. In addition, the high Li-ion transfer number (t Li+) also confirms the excellent Li+ transport of NbN@NHCR (Fig. S26). Fig. 4(c) compares the difference in cycling performances of the Li-S full batteries under a current density of 0.2 C. The NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li acquires a prominent discharge capacity of 1120 mA h g−1 and a high CE of 99% over 200 cycles with an insignificant capacity degradation rate of 0.053% relative to NHCR-S||NHCR-Li (762 mA h g−1, 0.29%) and NbN-S||NbN-Li (991 mA h g−1, 0.098%). Fig. 4(d) provides the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) profiles of the three cells. The NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li cell displays the smallest polarization potential of 186 mV compared to NHCR-S||NHCR-Li (281 mV) and NbN-S||NbN-Li cells (235 mV), owing to the excellent electrocatalytic activity with respect to the sufficient utilization of the LiPSs [36]. The ratio of the second and first discharging capacity plateaus (marked as Q2/Q1) reflects the catalytic activity of host materials, where Q1 corresponds to sulfur reduction into soluble LiPSs and Q2 relates to the subsequent transformation into insoluble Li2S2/Li2S [60]. According to the above results (Fig. S27), the NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li cell has a higher ratio of Q2/Q1 value (2.3) than other cells, indicating a better catalytic activity toward the subsequent conversion of Li2S4/Li2S2 to Li2S at the second discharging stage. As described in Fig. 4(e), the NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li cell reveals exceptional rate response and high cycle reversibility, showing average capacities of 1120, 981, 846, 755, and 667 mA h g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 C, respectively, with well-defined discharge plateaus at different current rates (Fig. 4f), verifying ultralow capacity degradation and small polarization. When it reverses back to the initial 0.2 C, an admirable capacity of 1068 mA h g−1 and a superb cycling stability over 50 cycles are well maintained. The corresponding GCD profiles of the two cells under different current densities are also presented in Fig. S28. By contrast, the NHCR-S||NHCR-Li cell undergoes severe capacity fading with the current rate increase. To establish the great merits of the NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li, the long-term cycling stability is additionally assessed at 2 C (Fig. 4g). The NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li cell displays a high capacity of 867 mA h g−1 with a low capacity fading of 0.031% per cycle over 1000 cycles among all the cells, highlighting a remarkable adsorption-catalysis behavior and suppressed shuttle effect. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of Li-S full cells before and after cycling was carried out to investigate the difference in charge transfer (Fig. 4h and i). As expected, the Nyquist plots and corresponding equivalent diagram prove that NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li maintains the smallest ohmic resistance (R e) and charge transfer resistance (R ct) before and after cycling, demonstrating the accelerated charge transfer and Li+ ions diffusion (Tables S4 and S5) [9,25]. Furthermore, a new semicircle can be monitored after cycling for all full cells, which is associated with the formation of the SEI layer, resulting from the deposition of insoluble Li2S/Li2S2 on the surface of electrodes during the discharge and charge process [61]. Post-mortem analysis was conducted to comprehensively reveal the LiPSs shuttle behavior of NbN@NHCR. As presented in Fig. S29(a–c), unlike the large yellowish brown LiPSs on the polypropylene (PP) separator for NHCR-Li anode side, the PP separator for NbN@NHCR-Li anode renders no obvious LiPSs, confirming that numerous LiPSs are well-confined on the cathode side. Furthermore, the surface of NbN@NHCR-Li anode depicts a rather smooth and dense appearance without obvious dendrites after repeated cycles (Fig. S30a). Apart from that, the NbN@NHCR-S cathode still retains well-maintained structural integrity during battery operation (Fig. S30b and c) and the NbN quantum dots can be clearly observed (Fig. S30d). Taken together, the above results demonstrate that the multifunctional integrated host for NbN@NHCR with superior lithiophilicity-sulfiphilicity inhibits shuttle behavior of LiPSs and Li dendrite formation simultaneously, which is highly competitive compared to previously reported Li-S full cells (Table S6). The ability of NbN@NHCR in suppressing the LiPSs shuttling was directly probed by in situ Raman characterization. The Raman signals were collected on the separator near Li anode side. As for NHCR-S cathode, the Raman signals of S8 2− detected at 152, 219, and 475 cm−1 during the initial discharging process correspond to the diffusion process of long-chain Li2S8 species, and get weaker gradually as discharge continues (Fig. 5 a and d) [30,60]. Subsequently, the Raman characteristic peaks of S6 2− (397 cm−1) and S4 2− (453 cm−1) start to emerge when discharges reach the second plateau for 2.09 V, which are attributed to the transform from Li2S8 to Li2S6/Li2S4, showing the serious shuttle behavior [9,42]. In contrast, all the peaks associated with LiPSs are no longer obviously strong in NbN-S cathode (Fig. 5b and e). When it comes to NbN@NHCR-S cathode, almost no signals are monitored in the in-situ Raman spectra, confirming the extraordinary capabilities of NbN@NHCR in immobilizing LiPSs and mitigating shuttle effect (Fig. 5c and f). For further obtaining a real-time visualization of the dissolution and diffusion behavior of LiPSs, a skillfully-designed transparent bottle cells of NbN@NHCR-S||Li device (or NHCR-S||Li and NbN-S||Li) were assembled with various cathodes and Li anodes in a pure electrolyte (Fig. S31). Specifically, the transparent electrolyte gradually changes to yellow upon discharging in NHCR-S||Li and NbN-S||Li cell owing to the weak interaction between NHCR and LiPSs. In sharp contrast, the electrolyte in the NbN@NHCR-S||Li cell almost remains a slight color change after lasting for 2 h, which is indicative of the high absorptivity of LiPSs by NbN@NHCR, thus effectively suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs and accelerating the redox kinetics. To understand the effect of synergistic enhancement mechanisms between catalysts and LiPSs at the atomic level, a series of theoretical calculations based on the adsorption and catalytic performance on the surfaces of NHCR (graphitic C, graphitic N, pyridinic N, and pyrrolic N atoms) and NbN (220) are studied by DFT. The optimized LiPSs adsorption structures at different lithiation stages (Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, Li2S8, and S8) are summarized in Fig. 5(g) and Figs. S32–S35. The results reveal that NbN possesses higher adsorption energy values at all lithiation stages than bare graphitic C, graphitic N, pyridinic N, and pyrrolic N (Fig. 5h). The coexistence of multiple adsorption sites ensures the effective capture of LiPSs by Nb–S and Li–N bonds, which is favorable for accelerating the charge transfer and promoting the complex electrocatalytic reactions on the NbN@NHCR-S cathode [46]. To further unveil the intrinsic mechanism of superior redox kinetics for NbN@NHCR, the Gibbs free energies for the stepwise disproportionation conversion (S8 → Li2S8 → Li2S6 → Li2S4 → Li2S2 → Li2S) during the discharge process were investigated (Fig. 5i and Fig. S36). The first reaction from S8 to Li2S8 is spontaneous exothermic conversion on pristine graphitic C, graphitic N, pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and NbN. The last solid-solid conversion steps (Li2S2 → Li2S) are endothermic processes, which turn out to be the rate-limiting step of Li-S battery to directly determine the whole discharging process [56,61]. It is worth noting that the conversion procedure of Li2S2 → Li2S is more thermodynamically favorable on the NbN surface (3.33 eV) with respect to graphitic C (4.04 eV), graphitic N (4.03 eV), pyridinic N (3.91 eV), and pyrrolic N (3.89 eV), which demonstrates that NbN is helpful in reducing the reduction barrier of LiPSs, enabling prompt redox kinetics and high efficiency stepwise sulfur conversion. In the subsequent charging process, the Li+ ion evolution course includes the fracturing of the Li–S bond and then moving away. The calculated decomposition barrier of Li2S on NbN (1.09 eV) (Fig. 5j and k) is lower than that on graphitic C (2.24 eV), graphitic N (1.12 eV), pyridinic N (1.76 eV), and pyrrolic N (1.90 eV) (Fig. S37), pointing to the easiest dissociation process of Li2S under the regulation of the polar and catalytically active NbN quantum dots centers, thereby significantly enhancing the decomposition process [39,54]. To intuitively make clear the mitigation of shuttle effects, static adsorption experiments were implemented to explore the chemical affinity of NHCR, NbN, and NbN@NHCR in immobilizing LiPSs by immersing the equivalent number of adsorbent samples in a 2 mM Li2S6 solution for 3 h. As witnessed in the inset of Fig. 6 (a), the solution containing NHCR remains brown and the solution including NbN shows gradual discoloration, while the solution with NbN@NHCR is almost colorless and in a transparent state compared to the brown of the original Li2S6 solution (Fig. S38), indicating that a synergistic combination of NbN quantum dots and NHCR contributes to enhancing the trapping ability toward LiPSs to suppress the shuttle effect [40]. Moreover, the UV-Visible spectra of supernatants confirm that NbN@NHCR curve has the weakest absorbance with the small amount of LiPSs in the solution, which is consistent with DFT calculation results. Moreover, in view of understanding the chemical interaction between NbN@NHCR and LiPSs, additional XPS measurements are also conducted. From the contrast of the XPS survey spectrum of NbN@NHCR before and after soaking in Li2S6 (Fig. 6b), a typical S 2p peak can be observed originating from the strong chemical anchoring between NbN@NHCR and LiPSs. Besides, the peaks in Nb 3d XPS spectrum shift toward lower binding energies (0.3 eV) after Li2S6 adsorption (Fig. 6c), illustrating an increased electron cloud density of the metal center via electron transfer between LiPSs species and NbN@NHCR [48,55]. The greatly enhanced LiPSs adsorption capability can be credited with the customized porous structure of high-density and conductive NbN quantum dots on the hollow carbon nanorods, thus providing abundant active sites for trapping and adsorbing LiPSs to alleviate the shuttle effect. For the sake of gaining full insight into the electrocatalytic activity of host materials for propelling the sulfur redox kinetics, a wide suite of tests was further conducted by employing a Li2S6 symmetrical cell configuration. The CV curves for both NbN and NbN@NHCR at a sweep rate of 5 mV s−1 explicitly present two sets of reversible redox peaks (Fig. S39a–c), which are mainly derived from the conversion from S8 to Li2S6 and then to Li2S [61]. On the contrary, the CV curve of NHCR symmetric cell only shows one pair of redox peaks, indicating sluggish sulfur redox kinetics. Additionally, the NbN@NHCR cell harvests the smallest polarization and highest peak current in comparison with other symmetric cells, intuitively signifying the facilitated conversion efficiency and enhanced catalytic activity. Moreover, the CV profile for the NbN@NHCR still sustains superior coincidence after five cycles (Fig. 6d and Fig. S40a and b), proving the relatively stable redox reaction of Li2S6 in the presence of the two electrodes. The excellent electrochemical reversibility of NbN@NHCR can be reflected by the boosted current response (Fig. 6e and Fig. S40c and d), in which two obvious redox peaks can be well sustained as sweep rate increases to 50 mV s−1 in the consecutive CV curves. The EIS spectra collectively substantiate the smallest charge transfer resistance for NbN@NHCR cell (Fig. S41), giving rise to the improved reaction kinetics and electrocatalytic activity [28]. The elevated catalytic effect of NbN@NHCR can be further demonstrated by Tafel plots (Fig. 6f). In this respect, NbN@NHCR cell delivers a higher exchange current density (4.6 × 10−2 mA cm−2) compared with NHCR (2.5 × 10−3 mA cm−2) and NbN (1.4 × 10−2 mA cm−2) in both anodic and cathodic processes, affirming the rapid electron transfer at the LiPSs/electrode interface in NbN@NHCR electrode [6,9]. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests in a three-electrode configuration display the remarkable catalytic ability for NbN@NHCR electrode (Fig. 6g), which delivers the earliest current response as well as the lowest onset potential of −0.50 V compared with NHCR (−0.45 V) and NbN (−0.40 V), evidencing the lowest energy barrier for the Li2S decomposition. Correspondingly, the lowest Tafel slope of 133 mV dec−1 for NbN@NHCR is superior to NHCR (207 mV dec−1) and NbN (169 mV dec−1), confirming the best catalytic performance (Fig. 6h). Chronoamperometry curves were obtained to research the redox kinetic behavior of different samples. As illustrated in Fig. 6(i), the NbN@NHCR symmetric cell harvests a higher current response in contrast to single NHCR and NbN, manifesting that NbN@NHCR is an efficient catalyst to motivate the redox reaction of LiPSs [42,50,61]. Additionally, Li2S nucleation/dissolution behaviors on NHCR, NbN, and NbN@NHCR electrodes were further evaluated. As witnessed in Fig. 6(j–l), NbN@NHCR delivers a higher Li2S precipitation capacity and earlier current response (233.8 mA h g−1 at 1510 s), much higher than NHCR (142.1 mA h g−1 at 2594 s) and NbN (94.4 mA h g−1 at 2605 s). Simultaneously, the NbN@NHCR also manifests the highest Li2S dissolution capacity (301.3 mA h g−1) with respect to NHCR (135.8 mA h g−1) and NbN (194.2 mA h g−1) (Fig. S42). It follows that NbN@NHCR can effectively expedite the solid-liquid conversion process with reduction nucleation of LiPSs and oxidation dissolution of Li2S in the sulfur electrochemistry [40,43,55], fairly coinciding with the above theoretical calculation analysis. To assess the practical application of NbN@NHCR scaffolds, the Li-S full cells were studied under high sulfur loading and lean electrolyte conditions. As exhibited in Fig. 7 (a), the initial areal capacities of 3.7, 5.2, and 6.3 mA h cm−2 were acquired under 0.2 C with 3.4, 5.5, and 7.1 mg cm−2 sulfur loadings, respectively, maintaining superior cycling stability after 150 cycles. More impressively, two well-defined voltage platforms can be well reserved under 7.1 mg cm−2 sulfur loading (Fig. 7b). Fig. 7(c) illustrates the rate capabilities of NbN@NHCR full cells under different sulfur loadings. The significant average capacities of 2.9, 4.1, and 5.4 mA h cm−2 are also preserved under 3.4, 5.5, and 7.1 mg cm−2 sulfur loadings, respectively, at a raised rate of 1 C, reflecting the improved Li electrochemistry kinetics and sulfur conversion reaction. As a proof of concept, the assembled NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li soft-package cell with a 5.8 mg cm−2 sulfur loading, corresponding to N/P (1.9:1) and E/S (5.2 µL mg−1), was fabricated. As indicated in Fig. 7(d), a favorable areal capacity (5.0 mA h cm−2) is able to be attained after subsequent 50 cycles, which evidently outperforms the common Li-ion battery (4 mA h cm−2). The corresponding GCD curves of pouch cell are presented in Fig. 7(e). More encouragingly, the charging and discharging platforms are still maintained clearly and the polarization is tolerable after continuous cycles, giving credit to the effective LiPSs management and dendrite inhibition provided by the synergetic effects of tailored nanostructure and composition in NbN@NHCR. For clarity, the foregoing catalytic conversion and Li deposition mechanisms for NbN@NHCR in facilitating the efficient synergy between both the cathode and anode are comprehensively proposed (Fig. 7f). (a) The meticulously designed hollow conductive carbon skeletons not only provide abundant interior space to host more sulfur species and expose a mass of active catalytic sites, but also accommodate the repeated volume variation of the S and Li upon cycling; (b) the sulfiphilic NbN quantum dots endow S cathode with strong chemical adsorption and superior catalytic reduction/oxidation capability to immobilize the LiPSs; (c) the lithiophilic NbN active sites render a high chemical affinity with Li+ ions and regulate uniform Li deposition and electrical field distribution behaviors to create a stable Li anode. 3 Conclusions In the study, we have presented a “one stone two birds” strategy to construct multifunctional NbN quantum dots anchored on ordered, interconnected, nitrogen-doped hollow carbon nanorods (NbN@NHCR) as LiPSs immobilizer and Li stabilizer at the same time for both sulfur cathode and Li metal anode. The comprehensive experimental results and DFT calculations demonstrate that NbN@NHCR efficiently immobilizes the soluble LiPSs and facilitates diffusion-conversion kinetics for alleviating the shuttling. The excellent rate performance and ultralong lifetime of the NbN@NHCR-S cathode can be harvested. When functioning as a Li host, the 3D ordered spatial structure integrated with abundant lithophilic sites is beneficial to homogenizing the distribution of Li+ ions flux and regulating uniform Li nucleation and deposition for suppressing Li-dendrite growth. The dendrite-free morphology and stable CE can be achieved in the NbN@NHCR-Li anode. Consequently, the assembled NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li full batteries deliver remarkable long-term cycling stability (a low decay rate of 0.031% per cycle over 1000 cycles at 2 C). Even at a high S loading of up to 5.8 mg cm−2 and a lean E/S ratio of 5.2 µL mg−1, the soft-package cell harvests a high areal capacity of 6.2 mA h cm−2 at 0.1 C. This study provides a viable avenue to simultaneously address the stubborn obstacles both in S cathode and Li anode for high-performance Li-S full batteries. coredata.dc:description: The shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and uncontrollable lithium dendrite growth seriously hinder the practical application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. To simultaneously address such issues, monodispersed NbN quantum dots anchored on nitrogen-doped hollow carbon nanorods (NbN@NHCR) are elaborately developed as efficient LiPSs immobilizer and Li stabilizer for high-performance Li-S full batteries. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental characterizations demonstrate that the sulfiphilic and lithiophilic NbN@NHCR hybrid can not only efficiently immobilize the soluble LiPSs and facilitate diffusion-conversion kinetics for alleviating the shuttling effect, but also homogenize the distribution of Li+ ions and regulate uniform Li deposition for suppressing Li-dendrite growth. As a result, the assembled Li-S full batteries (NbN@NHCR-S||NbN@NHCR-Li) deliver excellent long-term cycling stability with a low decay rate of 0.031% per cycle over 1000 cycles at high rate of 2 C. Even at a high S loading of 5.8 mg cm−2 and a low electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 5.2 µL mg−1, a large areal capacity of 6.2 mA h cm−2 can be achieved in Li-S pouch cell at 0.1 C. This study provides a new perspective via designing a dual-functional sulfiphilic and lithiophilic hybrid to address serious issues of the shuttle effect of S cathode and dendrite growth of Li anode.
